title: Tuesday, 29th November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning!

PM11:01am

Now we've even got rid of the masthead

PM11:02am

We literally can't give more room to content, both ours and yours

11:02 am

PM11:02am

BE11:09am

Here's the Opec preview: https://www.ft.com...-961e-a1acd97f622d

11:09 am
BE11:10am

Opec’s most powerful members were rushing on Tuesday to rescue a supply deal designed to end the longest oil price decline in a generation.

Saudi Arabia, Opec’s largest producer, and its arch rival Iran have set out their positions ahead of Wednesday’s ministerial meeting in Vienna, with the kingdom hinting it could walk away from a deal if its conditions are not met and Tehran publicly saying it cannot compromise on its production rights.

PM11:10am

Saudi really going to walk away?

PM11:10am

Guess anything can happen

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Well, yes. I don't know. And in terms of experts, those trying to predict where oil should be priced seem to be the least use of all of them.

BE11:11am

So let's on to some actual news.

undefined
11:11 am
PM11:11am

And so to BT

PM11:12am

Fudge

PM11:12am

Openreach separated legally but other wise everything the same

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Although we do get this chap as the new openreach chairman

PM11:12am

Mike McTighe

BE11:12am

(@Roddy: you can't copyright a colour. See International Klein Blue.)

11:12 am
PM11:12am

PM11:13am

Mike McT is a really busy chap

PM11:13am

I am not sure how he's going to fix this in

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Yeah, okay, so this needs a bit of context put on it.

BE11:13am

What Ofcom's done is said it's preparing a formal notification to the European Commission that it intends to force BT to legally separate Openreach.

BE11:14am

All of those words are required, which makes it a bit less dramatic than the average headline.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

And while the language is aggressive .....

BE11:14am

"We are disappointed that BT has not yet come forward with proposals that meet our competition concerns. Some progress has been made, but this has not been enough, and action is required now."

BE11:14am

There's also this .....

11:14 am
BE11:14am

“We remain open to further voluntary proposals from BT that address these outstanding concerns”

BE11:15am

So, it looks more like a threat than a promise.

BE11:15am

Call it an ultimatum, if you wish. But it's very far from an endgame.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

And note that it's a legal, but not a structural, separation.

BE11:15am

Actual structural separation would incur "materially greater costs and risks", including to the BT pension scheme, Ofcom decides.

PM11:16am

But how would / will it work from a shareholder ownership perspective?

11:16 am
PM11:16am

If they are legally separate, you'd have to have two listed entities

PM11:16am

I guess

BE11:17am

I think that'd be structural separation.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

All Ofcom wants is some kind of legal incorporation for Openreach, it seems. And whether it actually wants that, or just wants BT to act more serious in negotiations is unclear.

BE11:18am

Here's RBC.

BE11:18am

We believe BT will now be forced back to the negotiating table, where it faces a stark choice: Either to settle for a form of legal incorporation, or expect to be referred to the European Commission.
If BT goes down the route of fighting its regulator at the EC, we expect shareholders may start to call for a compete voluntary separation as an acceptable alternative.
Given BT’s more conciliatory overtures around the “red lines” of reporting lines and incorporation, we believe the most likely outcome now is that BT reaches a mutually acceptable solution with Ofcom.
Given the stock price has been under pressure from both regulatory and pension headwinds, a solution to the Openreach issue (and rising bond yields on the latter), BT could enjoy a substantial relief bounce in due course.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Note also that there's loads of time for BT to work something out, because Ofcom moves at the speed of a regulator.

BE11:18am

They're now beginning a public consultation for a submission to the Commission in early 2017.

BE11:19am

Also note that Ofcom needs to prove to the EC that its proposals are proportionate and work on a cost-benefit analysis.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

And BT has already been doing much of the functional-separation stuff Ofcom put forward in its June report.

BE11:19am

... including as you say -- and probably not coincidentally -- appointing Mike McTighe as the new independent Openreach chairman this very morning.

BE11:19am

All of which makes Ofcom's argument to the EC a wee bit trickier.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Here's Deutsche.

BE11:20am

Legal separation was already viewed as a better outcome for BT than full-fat separation which would incur additional pension costs and greater disruption. The sky is not falling in as a result of today’s news but the direction of regulatory travel is for further tightening after a period of loosening. We expect an eventual agreement but risk is that this gets bogged down in litigation. In the meantime the regulator pushes ahead helping BT’s competitors gain a greater fibre foothold which is more damaging for BT than a capex raise. Our other concerns for BT include the imminent launch of Sky Mobile, VMED's Project Lightning and convergence bundle discounting.

BE11:20am

They also provide a handy BT capex graph.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

PM11:20am

hmm

BE11:21am

.... Though one can argue that BT's network is already okay, relatively speaking, and covers a fairly compact landmass so doesn't need a load of investment.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Though I'm also in the camp that believes 99% of the population should be fine with copper wire rather than fibre, which I know is a minority view.

PM11:22am

Well, they haven't managed to stretch their cable as far as my house, in SE10, yet -- so copper is all i have

PM11:22am

fibre, not cable

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Well, here's Goldman.

BE11:23am

While it is disappointing there is no voluntary resolution, Ofcom’s formal request for legal separation does set out the clear boundary of what the regulator wants and limits further the risk of structural separation. From here, we expect Ofcom to consult on legal separation in the new year (likely 8-12 week process) and then formally put its proposals to the EC. In addition, Ofcom believes that it can largely mitigate costs to BT Pension but a sticking point clearly remains the reporting lines of the Opennreach CEO, which BT still believes should report to the BT CEO.

BE11:23am

And MOST.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Ofcom's concerns: The statement from Ofcom draws on the responses the regulator received from its July consultation. Ofcom highlights amongst its responses: 1. concerns on slow broadband speeds, availability of fibre and quality of service. 2. BT's concern on Openreach separation triggering higher pension costs as overstated.
Where do we go from here? Legal separation takes time to implement, especially as it is concerning employees and pension. Some investors were hoping for a definitive resolution, but today's result adds more uncertainty. Legal separation could take a number of years to implement and, in the meantime, there is the potential for further comments from regulator/ government (eg. Sharon White's comments on BT earlier this week to MPs) that could prove unhelpful. However, Ofcom does leave the door open to resume negotiations with BT to reach a swifter outcome.

BE11:24am

(@Pseudonym: ADSL at home. Think I pay about £15 a month. No complaints.)

BE11:24am

BT's decision to appoint an independent chairman of Openreach is an interesting (and likely positive) move. BT says this strengthens corporate governance and experience in dealing with regulators (the new chairman was previously employed at Ofcom). How practicable this arrangement will be (if there is a significant disagreement, for instance) remains to be seen. BT has also announced that the majority of the Board of Directors at Openreach are now also independent.
Referral to the EC perhaps adds another layer of complication - but BT has strong points to make. The inclusion of the European Commission potentially adds further complexity to reaching agreement – essentially, another party is added to an already complicated mix of interests and viewpoints (Ofcom, BT, unbundlers such as Sky/TalkTalk/Vodafone, the UK government, consumer Groups and now the EC). Interestingly, Ofcom and the EC had similar views of the proposed O2/3 merger. However, we would expect BT to point to its lower share of broadband customers (vs DT, Orange, TI etc) - and also its markedly higher VDSL coverage (than DT, for example).

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Mentioned on the right that this Mike McT chap was on the Ofcom board until this time last year

PM11:25am

You'd think there'd be more than 12 cooling off period when you've been at such a senior position at a regulator

PM11:25am

But Mike's a serial chairman

11:35 am

hmm

PM11:36am

BE11:36am

Otherwise ....... Ashmore I think is Citi.

11:36 am
Ashmore Group PLC (ASHM:LSE): Last: 274.00, down 10.7 (-3.76%), High: 282.40, Low: 269.00, Volume: 1.25m
BE11:37am


Performance Down — Daily priced ASHM SICAV funds are down 5% (External Debt) , 9% (Local Currency) and 6% (Blended Debt) since September. Corporate Debt is flat, but for greater than 70% AUM at ASHM, the mark to market looks challenging.

Fund Flow Risk
— US election outcome has been widely viewed as negative for EM.
Whether or not this is correct, we expect current market conditions to (at least) delay recovery in EM Debt fund flows at ASHM. Near term we also see outflow risk e.g. LCBF SICAV AUM is down 1 7% since end September, vs. NAV down 9%.

BE11:38am

Industry context
—
Investors pulled 2% of AUM from EM Bond Funds in the last two weeks. For context, the 2013 Taper Tantrum brought about 17 consecutive weeks of outflows (~10% AUM) from EM Fixed Income funds, May to September.

11:38 am
PM11:38am

That's painful context

PM11:38am

Potentially

BE11:38am

What's in our numbers
—
We scale back our forecast recovery. We now assume -8% cumulative negative returns from end September to June 2017E, then recovery to +5%-7% p.a. thereafter. Fund flows: we assume -$4.4bn (8%) net outflows Sep to Jun, zero FY18E and +$4.9bn FY19E. This gives us base case 268p price target.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Bull/Bear: on balance, more risk to the downside
—
It is possible EM fears are overplayed: rising US yields with fiscal stimulus and higher inflation could mean the “Trump Tantrum” is over quickly. We estimate 326p Bull Case value based on a return to positive returns Q4 Jun 17E and +$3.5bn net flows FY18E. But if returns remain flat and flows negative in FY18E: downside to Bear Case 204p is greater
.

BE11:40am

Dividend, operating margin questions could return
— Ashmore has demonstrated the resilience of its operating margin despite revenues falling since FY13, and maintained its DPS despite payout ratios greater than 85% FY15 and FY16. But if we see negative revenue momentum for longer, then questions on the sustainability of both could return. ASHM’s £364m net cash at end June 2016 falls to £85m June 2019E on our forecasts (DPS steps up fractionally each year despite lower EPS expectations).

BE11:40am

Sorry, that was painfully slow to cut and paste.

11:40 am
undefined
PM11:41am

Had you noticed that Credit swiss had stopped covering UK banks?

PM11:41am

I hadn't

11:41 am
PM11:41am

But in anycase they've started again

BE11:41am

.... good?

PM11:41am

And they like Barclays

11:41 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 214.25, up 2.35 (+1.11%), High: 216.50, Low: 210.85, Volume: 16.23m
PM11:41am

And they dont like RBS and StanChart

PM11:42am

Restructuring, litigation and regulatory risks: Tail/headwinds to CET1
ratios are significant and wide-ranging: +79bps (Barclays) to -170bps
(RBS) largely to due litigation risk differentials. The regulatory agenda is
heating up starting with the UK banks' stress test results on 30 November
for which we think banks are reasonably well placed. Our analysis of Basel
IV suggests a potentially significant impact for some UK banks, -4bps
(StanChart) to -190bps (RBS) however we expect IFRS9 to be manageable
(0-33bps impact). Our differentiated analysis of MREL (Minimum
Requirement for own funds and Eligible Liabilities) requirements suggest
HSBC will be the relative loser and Lloyds the relative winner.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Earnings risk skewed to the upside (ex-StanChart): We are above
consensus for adjusted earnings as we factor in a more benign UK macro
and the benefit of USD strength to Investment Banks (IB) earnings.
■ Barclays (OP, 260p TP) most preferred: Barclays presents the most
significant re-rating potential as visibility on group ROTE improves and the
restructuring benefit to CET1 is better understood.
■ StanChart (UP, 515p TP) least preferred. StanChart's valuation assumes
an 8% ROE is possible despite the need to grow the top line 20%. We
expect continued EPS downgrades to weigh on the shares.
■ For RBS (UP, 180p TP), the number of downside risks to EPS and capital
(plus the significant share overhang) places this as a relative underperform.
■ For Lloyds (N, 65p TP) fears over Brexit seem overdone; however, a
significant re-rating appears unlikely without a material surprise on DPS;
which we do not expect given Basel IV uncertainty.
■ HSBC (N, 600p TP) has outperformed fellow yield play Lloyds by 57%
since the EU vote and is now fully valued, in our view. Optimism around
higher US rates may be premature given MREL headwinds.

PM11:43am

Stress test results tomorrow

PM11:43am

Trader Gordon saying he's not interested

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Don't quite believe him on that

PM11:43am

We are mildly surprised by the level of continuing interest in the UK bank stress tests (results due tomorrow, 30 Nov at 7a.m.) We retain a negative stance on the FTSE100 bank sub-sector; our recommendations are Standard Chartered (Sell), HSBC (Sell), RBS (Sell), Barclays (Hold) and Lloyds (Buy), but this has nothing to do with possible stress test results. We expect RBS/STAN to remain loss-making in 2016e and (ex-Lloyds) none to achieve RoE

10% before 2019e at the very earliest. Is that not the real issue?

PM11:44am

We do not argue that the stress tests have (historically) been irrelevant. On the contrary, they have provided part of the justification for UK banks’ capital stacks being “strengthened” to current levels, (with a consequential impact on their now weak level of returns in perpetuity). However, both Lloyds and HSBC have already started (with regulatory approval) to return surplus capital via special dividends and buybacks. RBS aspires to follow suit (albeit we cannot now conceive of this happening before 2018, given outstanding pre-conditions relating to legacy conduct resolution and the Williams & Glyn disposal).

Barclays, with a CET1 capital ratio of “only” 11.6% at Q3 2016 remains “bottom of the league”. However, in our view, this is something of an irrelevance. We think that Barclays’ existing plans (primarily in relation to non-core run-off and an eventual disposal of Barclays Africa (BGA SJ, Not Rated), will (more than) address its current “notional” capital shortfall. We are not concerned at all.

11:44 am
PM11:44am

We do wonder whether stress tests are (in part) responsible for muddled thinking in relation to levels of actual impairment in 2017e. As discussed in our Lloyds note, Just how long can the sellside stay wrong? (28 Sept), we think the consensual expectation that Lloyds’ impairment charge will rise from £245m (11bps) in H1 2016 to £1,758m (40bps) in 2017e is quite absurd!

Meanwhile, for those investors seeking attractive investment returns (aside from Lloyds) we continue to recommend four names within the “challenger bank” sub-sector – Aldermore (Buy), Shawbrook (Buy), OneSavings (Buy) and Virgin Money (Buy). None of these are even subject to the stress test.

BE11:45am

Fair enough.

BE11:45am

Just to spin back, this is Credit Suisse restarting banks coverage after Carla Antunes da Silva quit being an analyst to become head of something or other at Lloyds.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

I .... think.

PM11:45am

I think you are right

PM11:45am

Replaced by Claire Kane

11:45 am
undefined
BE11:46am

Request wise, someone mentioned SSP.

SSP Group PLC (SSPG:LSE): Last: 372.00, up 30.2 (+8.84%), High: 374.20, Low: 342.00, Volume: 1.36m
11:46 am
BE11:47am

Record high, that. On better than expected FYs.

BE11:48am

Mostly on margin rather than revenue. Turns out selling £8 ham sandwiches at Gatwick is quite profitable, who knew?

BE11:48am

Here's Goldman.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

SSP reported strong FY16 results with EBIT of £121.4 mn, 5% above Bloomberg consensus, and 7% above at the EPS level, driven by stronger EBIT margin expansion than expected, up 70 bp (ex FX) to 6.1%, 20 bp above consensus. LFLs in 4Q16 were also slightly better than expectations at +2.8% (FY16 +3.0% vs. GSe: 2.8%; see table overleaf) with the slowdown vs. 1H16 caused by geopolitical headwinds (France, Belgium, Egypt) and slower growth in China. Net concession gains in 4Q16 were +1.0% (FY16 +1.7% vs. GSe: 1.8%). On the outlook, management highlights that FY17 has started in line with its expectations and that the company remains well placed to benefit from structural growth in the market.

BE11:49am

Analysis
Air LFLs stronger than rail: consistent with continued intra-European airline overcapacity supporting passenger volumes. Rail has been impacted by geopolitics in France, Belgium and other major European cities.
Operating profit
: FY16 EBIT of £121 mn is 5% above consensus and up
18% yoy (ex. FX). FY16 EBIT margin of 6.1% was 20 bp above consensus given slightly stronger LFLs than expected and some pre-opening costs delayed until FY17 (later timing of new unit openings).
Cash flow
: Net debt of £317 mn was 2% above consensus and was
negatively impacted by FX (net debt ex. FX would have been £278 mn).
Dividend
: FY16 dividend of 5.4 p/share was 6% above consensus.

BE11:50am

SSP trades on a CY17E P/E of 21.1x with a CY16-19E EPS CAGR of 12.8%. While we see SSP’s compelling earnings growth and progressive return on capital profile (CY17E ROIC of 15.8%) as attractive, this is reflected in its valuation. Our 12-month price target of 335p is based on P/E (20.7x 2017E)
vs. EPS growth (1yr fwd). Key risks:
higher/lower economic growth than
forecast, over/ under delivery of efficiencies, major contract losses, FX.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

FJP73 notes SSP's rail business, which I do find fascinating.

BE11:51am

In that SSP signed a bunch of agreements with Network Rail where its leases that run indefinitely, and demand a compensation fee on redevelopment.

BE11:52am

One can argue that rail stations are natural monopoly territory for a coffee shop. But if one were to argue that, one would get a furious letter from SSP's Feltcollaredsource so perhaps we'll just leave that there.
